abstract.p: State Sen Robert W Singer plans to introduce bill to sharply restrict privileges of teen-age drivers (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)

block.p: State Senator Robert W. Singer, a Republican of Lakewood, said he plans to introduce a bill on June 6 to sharply restrict the privileges of teen-age drivers.

The measure would require a novice driver to be accompanied by a licensed driver 21 or older for six months and forbid driving between 11 P.M. and 6 A.M. For a year after that, the driver could drive alone, but not between midnight and 6 A.M. except to go to work or religious services. During the entire period, the driver could not have more than one nonfamily member in the car and would have to maintain a spotless record.
State Senator Robert W. Singer, a Republican of Lakewood, said he plans to introduce a bill on June 6 to sharply restrict the privileges of teen-age drivers.

The measure would require a novice driver to be accompanied by a licensed driver 21 or older for six months and forbid driving between 11 P.M. and 6 A.M. For a year after that, the driver could drive alone, but not between midnight and 6 A.M. except to go to work or religious services. During the entire period, the driver could not have more than one nonfamily member in the car and would have to maintain a spotless record.
Currently, a 17-year-old in New Jersey can get an unrestricted license after holding a learner's permit for 20 days.
